awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary

This postdoctoral fellowship will support a two-year study that investigates the rise of evidence-based, talk-therapeutic interventions. The study will include institutional and historical analyses of documents from training organizations, accreditation requirements, insurance reimbursement guidelines, and journal publications. These data will complement the author's extensive ethnographic observations and interviews with clinicians to facilitate the publication of articles and a monograph. The author will engage in a concerted effort to disseminate the study's findings to practitioners. Moreover, this project will include opportunities for training undergraduate students in research practices and developing their interests in science and technology studies and the sociology of medicine. Lastly, this study will result in a teaching module focused on contestations around "evidence" in the psychological sciences. The module will incorporate both analytical perspectives and primary materials, and will be freely available on the web.

Technical Summary

The study will make four contributions to existing scholarship. First, it will illuminate the processes by which novel conceptual tools and practices travel between domains of knowledge; specifically, it will provide an account of how notions of "efficacy" and "evidence" originally associated with pharmaceutical drug testing came to be the standards in talk therapeutic research. Second, this study will shed light on contestations within the human sciences by demonstrating that the construction of credible knowledge that can travel between the research trial and the clinic depends on the mediation of insurance companies. Third, it will contribute to current debates about the status of the medical profession by suggesting that standards can solidify rather than undermine experts' jurisdictional and authority claims. Fourth, it will fill an empirical gap in existing literature by tracing the development and rise to dominance of a set of approaches that has been largely overlooked, namely cognitive behavioral therapies. The overarching goal is to show how the science of talk challenges the standard interpretation of the ascendancy of cognitive behavior therapies. Another explanatory mechanism advanced in this study is economic viability; it is used to focus attention on the co-constitution of particular notions of "good science" and an economic regime that favors standardizable conceptions of mental illness. These results will be relevant to policy-makers, clinicians, and patients. They will also contribute to ongoing debates in the psychotherapy field regarding the empirical validation of psychoanalytic interventions and the continued relevance of such practices in clinical work.

por.por_cntn:
When randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were first used after World War II for determining the efficacy of pharmaceuticals, their application in the field of psychotherapy must have seemed unlikely. This was especially so given the emphasis then placed not on “evidence-based” treatment, but on therapists’ capacity for empathy and appreciation for each patient’s individuality. Today, studying therapeutic efficacy by employing RCTs and relying on “evidence-based treatments” seem foregone conclusions, the inevitable outcomes of a turn to science in medicine at large. Rather than taking the diffusion and institutionalization of scientific psychotherapy as self-evident, this project investigates how data derived from randomized controlled trials came to define talk therapeutic research and practice, privileging cognitive and behavioral approaches (CBT) over psychoanalysis in the process.

 My research shows that cognitive and behavioral interventions are favored in today’s field of mental health.  This is especially apparent in research funding patterns, training programs, and the discourse of practitioners themselves. CBT’s rise can be attributed to its alignment with biopsychiatry, specifically, its adoption of Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorder disease categories, statistical measures, standardized tools, and randomized controlled trials. Its proponents have touted its claims to science and argued for broader dissemination. By this reading, “scientific” cognitive behavioral interventions overcame psychoanalytic “intuition-based” practices.

 I show that this neat narrative obscures a larger history of uncertainty and contestation. Early debates over randomization and the meaning of placebos in talk therapeutic clinical trials made the triumph of CBT anything but certain. Moreover, the evidence in favor of cognitive behavioral approaches is not quite as unequivocal as supporters would have it. For example, the American Psychiatric Association’s guidelines for treating depression (2010) point to other approaches, such as interpersonal psychotherapy, as more efficacious. For their part, psychoanalysts have been similarly concerned to establish the effectiveness of their interventions, starting as early as the 1950s. Though initially unsuccessful, in the past three decades, researchers have made sustained efforts to enhance the scientific profile of psychoanalysis. This has been partly accomplished by pursuing clinical efficacy research in line with the “gold standard” of evidence-based medicine, namely RCTs. Moreover, efforts to link psychoanalysis and neuroscience have resulted in the establishment of a new journal, Neuropsychoanalysis, and a new professional organization, the International Neuropsychoanalysis Society. At the same time, I show that what does set the psychoanalytic community apart from other therapeutic orientations is its deep and abiding skepticism towards the usefulness of research for clinical work. This, along with an organizational account of how research methods diffused in the field of mental health, helps to explain why these developments in psychoanalytic research have garnered less credibility than those in CBT.

These research practices cannot be understood in the absence of clinical work.  My book project compares the practical approaches of cognitive behavioral and psychoanalytic clinicians. A key dimension of “evidence-based” therapy practice has been the use of manualized interventions. Manuals provide standards for how psychotherapists ought to treat particular problems. However, mental illness has proven resistant to standardization and CBT clinicians are the first to acknowledge their difficulties in getting patients to follow manualized treatments. I shed light on the myriad ways in which clinical work is uncertain and complex, forcing clinicians to enroll a broader, unstandardized, set of tools to accomplish their goals. Specifically, I show that CBT clinicians borrow from their psychoanalytic counterparts an emphasis on emotions that I call “affective-relational knowledge”—a dimension of practice excluded from the manuals and structured clinical protocols depicted in CBT randomized controlled trials. 

Broader impacts: This project’s attention to the co-constitution of particular notions of “good science” and an economic regime that favors standardizable conceptions of mental illness is relevant to policy-makers, clinicians, and patients. It contributes to ongoing debates in psychotherapy regarding the empirical validation of psychoanalytic interventions and the continued relevance of such practices in clinical work. The author has engaged in a concerted effort to disseminate the study’s findings to practitioners. Moreover, this project has included opportunities for training undergraduate students in research practices and developing their interests in science and technology studies and the sociology of medicine. Lastly, the study has resulted in a teaching module focused on contestations around “evidence” in medicine that is part of a Sociology of Medicine course.
